headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Tiger Woods' Ex-Girlfriend Files Lawsuits Against Golfer And His Trust; FDA To Require Mammogram Reports Include Breast Density Information; Two Minneapolis Officers Rescue Elderly Couple From Burning Home. Aired 7:30-8a ET

utterances.speaker: MARK ESPER, FORMER DEFENSE SECRETARY UNDER PRESIDENT TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Of leaders in the Republican Party, and I think on both sides of the ledger we need a new generation of leaders.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Former Sec. Esper --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: ESPER
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right. Also this morning, Tiger Woods, in the sports world -- his ex-girlfriend has filed a lawsuit against Tiger Woods and his trust. We'll tell you why next.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: He's the most unlucky in love person.(COMMERCIAL)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Tiger Woods' ex-girlfriend has now filed two separate complaints after their six-year relationship ended.The first is a complaint filed against a trust that is owned by Tiger Woods. In it, Erica Herman claims that the pair had an oral agreement that allowed her to live in a home that was owned by the trust for five more years with all expenses paid. She says that Woods broke that agreement and locked her out of the home and she's suing for more than $30 million. Woods was served with a second complaint on Monday, we are told, and in it Herman is trying to free herself from a non-disclosure agreement that she signed back in 2017. She's citing the Speak Out Act that became law in December '22 -- December 2022. That's the federal law that prohibits the enforceability of an NDA if cases of sexual assault or sexual harassment arise after someone has signed it. [07:35:07] So for more on this fascinating conversation I want to bring in Jeff Benedict who is the co-author of the biography "Tiger Woods." And civil rights attorney and advocate Nancy Erika Smith who is best known for settling Gretchen Carlson's sexual harassment suit against Fox News and Roger Ailes. The two of you together are kind of like this powerhouse --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- to talk about this. (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's so good to see both of you. Good morning.

utterances.speaker: NANCY ERIKA SMITH, ATTORNEY, SMITH MULLIN, CIVIL RIGHTS ATTORNEY AND ADVOCATE
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Good morning.JEFF BENEDICT, EXECUTIVE PRODUCER, HBO DOCUMENTARY "TIGER", CO-AUTHOR, "TIGER WOODS":  Good morning.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Let's start with you, Jeff. What do you -- what do you make of all of this?

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's interesting to think about just these two things. We're talking about NDAs and trusts.And this is really about -- at the heart of this is a story about an athlete. A very prominent, world-famous athlete. And those NDAs and trusts are things you typically don't use in sentences when we're talking about sports. And I think Tiger is someone who has transcended athletics for so long he's a worldwide figure. He's one of the most recognizable people on the planet and there's a level of sophistication around him that most athletes never get near. And I think that's part of what you're seeing here is that it's the wealth, the fame, the fortune that he's had not for a little while but for a long while, since he was really -- since he was a teenager. And part of that is what's playing out here. NDAs are something that we ran into relentlessly when we were writing the biography of Tiger Woods.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Almost everybody we approached for an interview had signed one and it makes it complicated if you're trying to do that kind of research. But -- so that part doesn't surprise me -- the fact that there were NDAs signed. I mean, that's pretty typical status quo for Tiger.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Just quickly, how many people would you say had said that they had signed an NDA?

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: I don't know if I could give you a number. I'm telling you that --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That high? BENEDICT

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I've just been watching your face as he's been talking and I want to hear what you think. That's it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, I think NDAs are abusive. You shouldn't be able to commodify somebody's own life. To say to somebody you can't describe your own experiences in your own life while the other person can say whatever they want about you, which is what's happening here -- this specific allegation of Ms. Herman -- that he's out there saying whatever he wants and she's bound by an MBA -- NDA. And he's dragged her into arbitration, which is always secret.NDAs are what allowed Harvey Weinstein to abuse women for 30 years. NDAs allowed Roger Ailes to do it. They're usually used in an equal power relationship where somebody with power says to somebody without power your own life experience is now my property now. And the Speak Out Act was passed because it has allowed perpetrators of sexual harassment and sexual abuse to continue to have victim after victim after victim. So that's why the Speak Out Act passed. Unfortunately, it only applies to pre-dispute signing of an NDA which, in fact, she did in this case. Ms. Herman worked in his restaurant.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Did that change it --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: She was both an employee --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- because she was an employee?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: It doesn't change it because she's an employee, but it makes it more complicated because she's an employee. And she did sign it, clearly, pre-dispute -- five years pre-dispute. Five years before he allegedly tricked her to get her out of the house and brought her -- said she was going on a vacation.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But -- and no one can -- I don't think anyone can dispute what you're saying but what if someone is -- if you are a person of note, right -- a high-profile person and you have someone just say coming in doing work for you or what have you, you don't want them disclosing conversations that happen in your home or private things that they may see in your home. Do you understand what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I absolutely understand it. If she was showing his checkbook to people --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- or things that are totally private and not about her experiences.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right. SMITH

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You know him really well. I mean, you've interviewed him. You've interviewed people around him. You've written books on him.He has been through -- I mean, his whole life is just such as fascinating thing. But also recently he had the car accident. He's been trying to make this comeback. What do you -- what do you reflect on when you think about him as a person navigating this situation?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: What their intentions are.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: That's right. It's -- there's a -- there's a level -- I'm not making any excuse here; I'm just saying there's a level of complexity around that level of celebrity that is not normal even for star athletes. And there is only a few people -- Tiger, to me, is much more like a showbiz entertainer at the very top. He's one of the most recognizable people on the planet.So we quickly realized, like, right down to the housekeeper or the person who comes over to walk his and Elin's dogs is signing an NDA. It's partly because he's got sophisticated lawyers around him. Agents that most people don't have. They're the ones who produce these documents and ask people to sign them. It is a little bit different than Harvey Weinstein's situation where women are being asked to sign NDAs on the back end after a bad thing has happened and they enter into a settlement. Most of the time, in this case -- in Tiger's case, people are signing NDAs when they meet him or when they go into business with him, or they enter some kind of relationship with him. That's what happened here. I'm not saying it's a good or bad thing but it's a little different. LEMON:  Because you don't want people to profit off of -- potentially, come in and profit off of your personal --

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Well, partly that. But also, Don, I think we have to remember where Tiger has been.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: I mean, that -- what he went through in '08, '09, '10 -- his own making -- I mean, this was a situation that he created. But in the aftermath of that mess that was made, we saw one of the most public spectacles for a professional athlete in the world that we've ever seen.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I've got to go but I know you want to --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: This isn't a housekeeper. Yes, this isn't a housekeeper. This is an intimate relationship he had with a woman and having her sign an NDA about her own experiences in that relationship is very different than saying the housekeeper shouldn't reveal what the kids got on their homework.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: I don't -- I don't disagree with you. I'm not saying it's the same as that.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: I was just trying to say it's different than Harvey Weinstein.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's nuanced.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Kind of par for the course.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And we do thank you both. I appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And we do need to say that CNN reached out to Woods' representatives for a comment but did not immediately receive a response.Jeff Benedict and Nancy Erika Smith, thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BENEDICT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This morning the FDA is announcing new regulations for mammograms for the first time in 20 years. Your mammogram report is now going to include information about breast density, which is really important because apparently, women -- according to science and their studies -- with dense breasts are at a higher risk for breast cancer actually and dense tissue can make it harder to detect cancer in these mammograms.Joining us now is the chief of breast surgery at Mount Sinai Health System, Dr. Elisa Port. Who better than to break this down? OK, so what are they looking at? What are they changing? Why is this such a thing that they haven't considered before but need to now? DR. ELISA PORT, CHIEF OF BREAST SURGERY, MOUNT SINAI HEALTH SYSTEM: Sure. So I think it's important to know that some of it is changed but some of it is not. Understand that starting in 2009, a number of states have already enacted legislation about informing patients of their breast density or informing their doctors. What the FDA is now doing -- and we're now up to 38 states that have legislation. What the FDA is doing is saying now everyone has to do it. All states have to do this.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: And more importantly, Kaitlan, we have to inform the patients themselves. So it's a much more consistent and --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: -- uniform regulation.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So they're looking at these regulations.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This is what we're going to see be different, right?

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Right. So, number one, the patients themselves have to hear about their breast density and that's going to be in the form of an added paragraph of text in the person's mammogram report that they receive.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Number two, it has to explain how breast density can influence the accuracy of a mammogram. And I guess we'll talk about that in a minute with our pictures showing that if a woman has a lot of density it can make it more difficult to pick up a cancer and she should consider doing additional types of tests that may -- that may prevent that --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: -- missing.And obviously, this makes this more of a national initiative rather than a state-by-state kind of decision.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And so, strengthening their oversight -- it just means basically making sure all states are on the same page here.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: And compliant and -- it's a regulatory compliance.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, you don't want to be different. Breast cancer is not different state to state. You don't want to be different.OK, I'm fascinated by --

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- all of this because I didn't really know much about this until Katie Couric came out with her story talking --

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- about this and how much of an issue it was.So what are the doctors looking for here?

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Sure. So, as you can see here, as the map says, less dense tissue shows up as darker on a mammogram. More dense tissue shows up as whiter, OK? A cancer is usually a white ball or little white speckles on a mammogram. So it's really easy to imagine how a white ball or white speckles against this background -- the proverbial polar bear in a snowstorm --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: You know, for us -- those of us who are in the trenches trying to -- it's all about saving lives. And it's very important for people to know that mammograms do save lives by picking up cancers earlier. And equally as importantly, they save lives while doing less.You know, if you find a cancer earlier you're way more likely to be able to have smaller surgery, OK, which some women would much prefer. You're way less likely to need more aggressive treatment like chemotherapy. So saving lives and picking up cancers earlier is our number one goal and always has been.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: And if this leads more women, number one, to get mammograms and number two, to get additional tests they might need -- they might need if mammograms miss something, it's a win.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.Dr. Elisa Port, thank you for explaining all of that.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That is such critical information and thank you for breaking it all down for us and using the magic wall for the first time. We'll bring you back on election night.

utterances.speaker: PORT
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I'm all -- I'm all tutored up now -- OK.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much.OK. Also this morning, the cartel that is believed to be responsible for the armed kidnapping of four Americans -- this is a development we've been tracking all week here -- now appears to be saying sorry? What's inside the alleged apology? That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Plus, this new video of an incredible rescue out of Minneapolis.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: OFFICER ZACHERY RANDALL, MINNEAPOLIS POLICE
utterances.sentences: It was like OK, guys, the house is on fire. We need to get out.

utterances.speaker: OFFICER JAMAL MITCHELL, MINNEAPOLIS POLICE
utterances.sentences: Come on out. Get down. Get down. Get down. Get down.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Two Minneapolis police officers are being recognized for thinking fast and literally running into danger after finding themselves the first to arrive to a burning home. They sprang into action without a single thread of protective gear.CNN's Adrienne Broaddus has their story in this week's Beyond the Call of Duty. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) ADRIENNE BROADDUS, CNN CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  As smoke from a burning home in Minneapolis filled the sky --

utterances.speaker: CHIEF, BRYAN TYNER, MINNEAPOLIS FIRE DEPARTMENT
utterances.sentences: They didn't even know the house was on fire.BROADDUS (voice-over):  -- a couple in their 80s was in danger.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: It was a two-alarm fire.BROADDUS (voice-over):  But before this fire crew arrived --

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: Police! Anyone in here? Call out!BROADDUS (voice-over):  -- Officer Zachery Randall and Jamal Mitchell were finishing a call nearby. They were the first to respond.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: Start me fire or send me EMS. I've got someone upstairs calling for help.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: There was confusion. I mean, it was like OK, guys, the house is on fire. We need to get out.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: Come on out. Get down. Get down. Get down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I don't have any shoes on.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: That's OK. Get out.I remember stepping in that house and just seeing a thick cloud of smoke and not being able to breathe normally.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: It's all right. Get down. Get down.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: There's some sprinklers going off and that's why my feet are wet.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: That's OK.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: So I just kind of grabbed her by her hands and I just kind of helped her down the stairwell. Are you alone, ma'am?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No. My husband is right behind me.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: So that was lucky, too, that he was right behind her on that because I don't know how we would have found anyone, much less without respirators or any of the fire equipment.CHIEF BRIAN O'HARA, MINNEAPOLIS POLICE:  Police officers are not trained to run into fires. They are not equipped with the protective equipment and breathing apparatus to go into a fire.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: We're not trained to run into fires but we are trained to put others' lives in front of ours. So when we found out possibly that someone was in that house we didn't second-guess running in to make sure no one was in there.O'HARA:  I mean, three days before Officer Mitchell was in this situation, I had literally just sworn him in as a police officer, so he was brand new.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: Third day on the street for Minneapolis -- yes.O'HARA:  You know, I'm incredibly thankful for Officers Randall and Mitchell and just impressed. BROADDUS (voice-over):  And so is the fire chief Bryan Tyner, who said it took two hours to fight this fire, which is now an arson investigation.

utterances.speaker: TYNER
utterances.sentences: And witnesses actually saw somebody throw an incendiary device through the window.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Flames burned through the roof leaving this massive hole.

utterances.speaker: TYNER
utterances.sentences: Well, it could have been pretty tragic. I mean, it honestly could have resulted in the fire death. We're very fortunate that they were where they were.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I'm cold, yes.

utterances.speaker: MITCHELL
utterances.sentences: OK. We've got shoes out here for you, ma'am.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: I think we were fortunate enough to be in the -- in the right spot at the right time on someone's most unfortunate day. And we were just able to help someone out.Is there anyone else in the house, guys?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: RANDALL
utterances.sentences: OK.BROADDUS (voice-over):  Adrienne Broaddus, CNN, Minneapolis. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Running towards danger.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes, amazing story.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: CNN THIS MORNING continues right now.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Mr. President, did you know about the $130,000 payment to Stormy Daniels?DONALD TRUMP, THEN-PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES:  No, no.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Then why -- why did Michael Cohen make this if there was no truth to her allegations?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, you'll have to ask Michael Cohen. Michael is my attorney and you'll have to ask Michael Cohen.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: Do you know where he got the money to make that payment?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: No. I don't know -- no.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, they did ask Michael Cohen, right?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: There are so many seminal moments from the Trump presidency but that simple question is one of them --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: -- because it was a moment that was on camera and now it's been used so many times.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, you're right. That moment stands out to everyone on the plane. Were you on the plane when they did that?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: No. That was a pool reporter. I think it was Katherine (INAUDIBLE) who did it. It was amazing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I wonder if people were shocked? I think they were when he came back and actually answered that question.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, because it -- we've seen how it's played out in cases in the past and how it may be playing out now.Good morning, everyone. Poppy, as you can see, is off here today. What Don and I are talking about after these years of denials there is new reporting from The New York Times that former President Trump may soon face criminal charges in that Stormy Daniels hush case that he was being asked about there.
